any means
I say it's authentic because I am from
the Caribbean and the food is inspired
by the Caribbean
[Music]
my name is Ralston Williams I'm the chef
and owner of the food sermon kitchen in
Brooklyn I grew up in a in the village
for hotels and since and Grenadines and
this happens a lot in immigrant
communities so my dad was in the States
he was a sailor sailing our ship he
sends for my mother lets her know that
okay eventually we'll work the papers
out the immigration papers so that we
can send for Ralston one day my mom
comes to the States expecting to work
and get this papers processed in a
couple of months took seven years I was
raised by a friend of my mom my name is
Gloria
mykola aunty she had what's called
rheumatoid arthritis and rheumatic fever
and so she was often bedridden so she
would shout down from her bed through
the window down for me as a little boy
five six years old from running back and
forth into the kitchen as she's telling
me ingredients of what to get and that's
where you know it began my my
perspective and outlook on food and my
love affair with food began I came to
the States and 1987
I remember today September 24th 1987 it
was
it was different I have an instant
family I with mom and dad and two
brothers that I didn't have when I was
in the islands I just it was me and my I
was raised basically like an only child
I went to school in Huntsville Alabama
to study theology I wasn't about to be a
minister I changed so many times I ran
out of money I didn't really apply
myself too much I moved back to to New
York and I started cooking privately I
had to do some catering and so I had to
come up with a name so say in the end of
my bed I'm like what is my message what
is my purpose now you know just a little
quiet moment I say well if I had
followed through with becoming a
minister I would be preaching the word
but my message now is food so the food
sermon and now I realize that everyone
really has a food sermon is really just
your perspective on food that you're
experiencing in life that actually shape
your outlook on what you need how you
prepare ingredients that kind of thing
that is really the food sermon so you
can get a fish bowl and get a lamb a
braised lamb shank a jerk chicken bowl
and you can also get tofu veggie bowl
with your choice of rice and beans that
kind of thing the gentleman came by says
I've heard about your place I want to
give you a gift figured it's an artist
he wants to paint something I'm good so
I just gave him this photo I took the
local butcher was preparing his meats
for sale we were joking around with one
of the local guys how handsome the cow
look compared to him and I got think and
he puts through the cow head on and I
had my camera to snap it he captured the
essence of who we are as Caribbean
people we live off the land it could
because these will have been a bowl of
fruit in his head or a bunch of banana
like that and he came back with this
ridiculous painting which I love so much
it has become the symbol of the food
sermon in really in God's providence for
my life I really believe that my
immigration papers not working out and
me having to stay in the islands as a
little boy for over 70 years and
learning how to foundation of what
flavor learn how to cook and that kind
of thing
prepared me for this in reference to my
homeland I love that place
it's my one sole desire is to go back
there and actually live there be able to
be part of the food scene there I think
my role eventually would be to get down
there and really like help to preserve
what may seem to be fading out of our
traditions and things like that
so when you show up here and you know I
get calls the flappity and stuff like
that I really honestly think it's a joke
I don't really think these things are
happening to me because this is
something that I would do if no one's
